dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILSON steps out into the late sunlight and the heat of t day.  A slow-motion moment while he gets acclimatized.  H wouldn't have ever felt quite this kind of heat before. After such a rigorously air-conditioned interior.  Or see cops wearing guns on their belts.  Or black cops, for tha matter, with guns on their belts.  Or seen people as fat Americans on their home turf.  Things someone from Englan notices immediately, whether consciously at first or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson's not here for comfort.  Shown to a shitty room, r the corner of a typical 2nd-level outside walkway.  Airpo close by. INT. MOTEL ROOM.  EVENING. He draws a curtain open across a window in one strong eas glide.  His moves are neat.  His expressions just as economical, not giving much away.  Outside the planes are practically on top of us. The sunset colors strange and chemical. He's only got one light bag.  Unzips, unpacks a few thing Change of clothes, a travel kit, and some familiar items (shaving foam/toothpaste/deodorant} bearing unfamiliar British brand names. Goes into the bathroom.  Turns on the shower in there. Comes back to sit on the bed.  Takes an envelope out of h jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ENVELOPE
dialogues.text: Turns it over to see the return address on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson in the back.  Stares at the impenetrable name on t driver's posted ID. Glances at the driver. DRIVER glances back at his quiet passenger in the rearvie mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson walks up a cracked little path to the front door. Lower middle-class street.  Two cars in the driveway, one behind the other.  Lights on inside the house -- as he ri the bell.

dialogues.speaker: ED RAMA
dialogues.text: Answers it.  Hispanic.  Late 30's.  Chairman Mao on his T shirt notwithstanding, an easygoing sort of fellow.  Not looking for any trouble -- anymore.  But once did, and ab to handle himself if any shows up.  Which it has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward Rama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eduardo. (rolling the R)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're home, then. He turns, waves away the taxi he's kept waiting.  While Eduardo Rama waits for an introduction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Wilson. Accent speaks for itself.  Hard, working-class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson? Knows the name.  But just now it's unexpected.  He's hold a hot TV dinner, hand protected by a dish towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote to me about my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed takes Wilson inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't expect anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, what has it been -- six months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Round about, yeah. They've entered a cauldron of family life.  TV blaring (SHOWBIZ TONIGHT!).  A couple of younger KIDS yelling "Ma Their MOTHER shouting back at them from the kitchen (in Spanish) that she only has two hands.  A sullen TEENAGER walking by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even know who I was writing to -- just someone with the same last name. She never talked about any family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was better than a telegram. Ed opens a screen door to the backyard. EXT. ED'S BACKYARD.  NIGHT. They sit at an outdoor table.  Wilson with a TV dinner in front of him now too.  Sounds from inside MUTED.  Even th little house has a little pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who done it, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snuffed her. Ed surprised at Wilson's directness.  Ed stands nervously

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, wait up a second, man. And paces back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said nothin' about nothin' like that.  No, no, no.  That's not what I wrote to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but between the lines, eh? Mysterious circumstances, and that. Ed stops pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I sent you that newspaper clipping, all right?  I told you what I know.  It was an accident.  I didn't say anything about anybody being "snuffed." Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This bloke she was bunked up with.  This Terry what'sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine.  What's he got to say for himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.  What's he gonna say?  They had a fight that night, she drove away, she was upset?  I don't even know the guy. Don't get me wrong, Jenny and me were friends, but we didn't travel in the same social circles.  She had her life, I had mine. Makes a kind of scoffing gesture:  and you can see what m life is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine came into the restaurant where I work with Jenny a couple times.  He's a money guy.  Jenny would say, hey, here's my friend Eddie and he would shake my hand and everything, but he wouldn't even see me, you know what I mean. Wilson gazes up at the sky.  Clear night.  Stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long had she been in the States? (as if to himself, somewhat wistful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near on ten years, wasn't it?  Long enough to know her way about, I reckon. Ed leans down, palms on the tabletop, facing Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was an investigation, okay?  The car was totalled.  Jennifer was ... Her neck was broken.  On impact, they said. So she wouldn't have ... felt the effects of the fire. (helpless shrug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens up there.  Happens a lot. What more can I tell you. Wilson taps out a cigarette from a pack of "Silk Cut" he' produced from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What more is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just sayin' -- it was a steep hillside.  There was no moon that night ... Wilson's quiet stillness is getting to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda happened to anyone, man.  I never knew her to be reckless.  I mean, sure, she would smoke a little grass, or something, have a few drinks.  But that's it, nothing more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not my girl.  Self-control, she had. Point of pride. (smokes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And people don't change, do they.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno ... Maybe they do. Wilson notes the tattoos on Ed's forearms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going straight, are ya. Ed looks at him.  Sits down again.  Keeping his forearms the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boomerang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew when I was droppin' that letter into the mail slot it was gonna come back and smack me in the face. (looks at Wilson again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did my time, okay?  My sister, her ol' man's up in Chino right now doin' eight years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re the family inside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't your lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kiddin', man?  I don't need a wife and screamin' kids.  I still got my youth. And yet -- he lives here.  Wilson declines to pursue the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to work, try to keep my life together, put all that shit behind me, man.  What d'you want from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly smoking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only asked. Ed sighs.  Reaches for one of Wilson's cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple weeks before she died, Jennifer asked me to drive her downtown. Said she was meeting -- her boyfriend -- Valentine. But I think she was looking for him. FLASH CUTS: ED AND JENNIFER. In a car, downtown. She has the same ste intensity as her father. Ed looks a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting Ed's cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, tryin' to catch him with another bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought, man.  But it was not a hotel or nothin' that we went to. It was someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where abouts? FLASH CUTS: JENNIFER. Talking to a beefy SUPERVISOR. Or talking at hi Either way, he isn't happy. MEAT PUPPETS. Watch instead of working. ED. Taking all this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad place, man.  Bad people.  Some guys loading some trucks.  Some kinda deal goin' down. (anticipating Wilson's next question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know and I don't care.  Maybe they're shipping fava beans to Eskimos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Jenny know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine wasn't even there.  If he was into something, if she was involved -- who can say. (stands up again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll tell you something.  She stood in front of these dudes, man.  Eyeballing them.  Checking them out. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt like she was covering my ass that day. Unconsciously rubbing his arms where his tattoos are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drove her back to Valentine's house. FLASH CUT: VALENTINE. Standing in front of his house. His expression says: We have something to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was standing outside waiting for her. That's the only other time I ever saw him. (a short sad note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time I saw her. He meets Wilson's gaze.  As hard and pointed as a drill through his skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed drives Wilson back to his motel.  Wilson silent.  Ed s not quite sure who he's dealing with.  Is this really or merely a grieving dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gonna do, man?  You gonna go to the cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, coppers don't do nothing, do they.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those streets up in the hills, man. Gotta be real careful, keep your eye on the ball.  Two o'clock in the morning, it's dark, your mind is all agitated, you're drivin' a little too fast ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those curves don't kid around. Could be talking about the girl.  Wilson doesn't move.  B touch him, he'll explode.  Out the window lights are pass but no landmarks.  He might as well be on the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should talk to Elaine.  That was her best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't write to me, did she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't know what to say. (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought someone should say something. To someone.  With me it was, I don't know -- Jenny liked me for some reason.  I felt like I owed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd Jenny get it off of -- this grass or whatever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self-conscious again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me, man.  I'm no drug dealer, what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re Ed's tattoos)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you didn't get that lot in the Navy, doing your National Service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already told you, man.  Corcoran.  Know what that is?  State prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick's a nick, n' it?  No matter what state you're in.  State of remorse, most likely -- for gettin' caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not me anymore.  That's when I was into the gang lifestyle.  That's not who I am now.  Five years in the joint -- that's it for me, man. Now Wilson drops the clanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just got out meself, didn't I. And Ed turns.  Looks at Wilson.  Fellow ex-con.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson out of the car, shuts the passenger door.  Ed on t other side, looks over the roof at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, man. (plane taking off in background)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on a plane. Wilson has other plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be needing a shooter. Makes his fingers like a gun.  And a clicking sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes quickly over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kiddin' me, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do, then, look in the bleedin' Yellow Pages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an urgent whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are not guys you can just go run a number on, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought perhaps there'd be dispensing machines, you know.  Bung in your coins, come out with a .44 Magnum, fully-loaded. Ed throws up his hands, walks back to his driver's side d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a resident of California? You gonna fill out forms, man?  Do the background check?  Go through a three-day waiting period?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sod that.  Gotta get back before my probation officer wonders where I've skived off to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probation?  Man, you crazy.  They shouldn't've let you outta your country, much less prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travelling on a dodgy passport, n' all. Walks round to come face to face with Ed once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why I thought, save some time, get what I need under the table, like.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: As if resigned and mulling the problem over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of tables.  Under bright lights.  Displaying eve kind of firearm.  Handguns, rifles, shotguns, parts to ma machine guns.  A weapons bazaar.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON AND ED
dialogues.text: Walking around.  Even a cool customer like Wilson can't h but be impressed by America's loving embrace of senseless mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: DEALERS
dialogues.text: Touting their wares.

dialogues.speaker: VISITORS
dialogues.text: Trying out pistol grips -- or pushing baby carriages.  Gu in fatigue jackets with toddlers on their shoulders.  Wom in stretch pants looking for a little something in person protection.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Doesn't know where to look.  At the booth featuring "Clas Cowboy Collectibles" -- or the most OBESE COUPLE he's eve seen who just walked by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attention:  the long-range vermin- shooting panel is due to commence in two minutes in the blue room at the rear of the Convention Center. ... and other anomalous oddball ANNOUNCEMENTS in the background as long as we're here.

dialogues.speaker: DEMONSTRATION
dialogues.text: At a booth selling laser attachments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BeamSight II is easily mountable on any shotgun, rifle, or sidearm and will project a small, bright red dot directly onto the point where your weapon is aimed ... For purposes of display, a smiling YOUNG WOMAN is the "target."

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Walking past, almost subliminally noting the Young Woman the symbol of death on her.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: A .45 passed from a DEALER's hand to Wilson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man knows what he likes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he'll talk if Wilson won't)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookin' good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while Wilson checks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a high-end item.  Total reliability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you call that -- the Protector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  Won't find a better CQC on the market. Wilson's eyes glance up -- but Ed asks the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CQ what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close Quarters Combat.  Keep one in my own home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble is, I'm not at home, see. Fancied a bit of target shooting, y'know, while I'm here -- with me mate. Nods at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really?  Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: England. (sighting the weapon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only, we saw there was a show on, thought I might pick something up for a price, type of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came to the right place, sir.  My wife's second cousin is English.  Well, Scotch-Irish.  Can I interest you in a holster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just luck, this, really.  Never been to one of these before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in gun country now, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up another, checks it out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been to the Boat Show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re Wilson's new selection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packs a punch, but it's compact, has accessible features -- makes a nice concealed-carry piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing the reluctant buyer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't have a concealed weapons permit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have time for a lot of paperwork, y'know.  Just popped over on a quick visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.  If you don't have a problem with me reporting this gun stolen. A look of understanding between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Not at all. (to Ed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's already a steal, n'it -- what you said -- four hundred for this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll have to add another two hundred on top of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, aye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... for the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed drives.  Nervous at Wilson handling his new gun purcha beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violation of my parole, this. (a perfect pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Goin' abroad. Ed shakes his head at Wilson's sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hadda show up on a weekend.  This weekend.  Wouldn't've even been a gun show ... for another month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking out of order, that.  Shouldn't be allowed. As he puts away a box of ammo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what.  You gonna take your new arsenal, go visit Terry Valentine, just like that?  Boom bam boom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only insurance.  Can't be too careful.  This Terry Valentine, he's probably a wonderful fella.  They were together how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years, I think.  Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there you are.  Jen must've liked him. Doesn't make Ed feel any better.  Nor does the way Wilson seems now to be studying Ed's driving techniques.  Paying attention to the way traffic lights and left-turn lanes a cars without clutches work over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny told me she met him at the beach. Got blinded by his smile. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that shit?  Son of a bitch never smiled at me.  Buried her at a "private" service.  Private for who. Him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang about.  I thought you said he come into the restaurant where you worked with Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came in with Jenny to the restaurant where I work.  That's not where they met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's where you met Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- Jenny used to work as a waitress.  Before she met him.  But that's not where she met me.  Not in my restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd the two of you hook up, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jenny was in my acting class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson at the wheel himself.  Getting the hang of L.A. Driving downtown.  Along one of the major boulevards. Glances at a street sign as he goes by.  Picks up the map book on the seat beside him to check his route. EXT. BOULEVARD.  DAY. Wilson makes a sudden lane change to avoid getting fed in wrong direction.  Gets HONKED by another driver. EXT. A STREET DOWNTOWN.  DAY. Wilson cruises past a particular building.  We don't have really clearly see it just yet (we saw it in the flash cu more important we see him seeing it.  Casing it with the of a professional.  Sniffing it out; the instinct of a predator after prey. INT. CAR.  DAY. Parks it.  Produces the little leather travel kit we saw unpack at his motel.  Unzips it.  Under the usual assortm of clippers, razors, etc., is a hidden layer -- storing s more personalized items:  a set of select slim lockpicking/cutting tools. EXT. SIDE STREET.  DAY. Wilson locks the car.  Walks away.  STAY with him.

dialogues.speaker: AROUND THE CORNER
dialogues.text: He walks down the block.  A nice long walk.  What we get of it besides a sense of Wilson -- cool cat; ambling alon loner; sun beating down; not bothered; his shadow doublin him -- is this: The building approaching.  The one he has his eye on.  Th target.  It's across the street.  A kind of flat windowle warehouse with adjoining loading yard.  Loading yard surrounded by a chain-link fence -- topped with barbed wi The actual geography of where he left his car in relation this building.  Safely around the corner.  And how he mig practically get back to it, either this same way or via a more circuitous route round another block. The sense you get in downtown L.A. on a lazy Saturday afternoon that you're in a ghost town.  Particularly in t shabby kind of industrial section. EXT. THE BUILDING. Wilson crosses over to it now.  From sunny to shade. Walks past the chain-link fence.  The padlocked gate, big enough to accommodate the (couple of) trucks parked withi the compound. Walks past the closed security door which would appear to the building's main entrance. Round the next corner -- SEES there's a steel back door a well. Comes around this block again.  Looking surreptitiously a now.  Streets here utterly deserted.  Not even a passing Crappy residential building on an opposite corner, SPANIS MUSIC blaring from one of the open windows, but not with direct view on the loading yard fence on this side.  Wils nearing it now -- taking something out of his pocket.  On the mysterious metallic tools from his travel kit.  Snaps wrist, unfolding the tool with a CRACK.  Wire cutters. He doesn't go for the gate, the padlock, like we might ha thought.  He suddenly drops to one knee, in shadow where fence meets the adjoining building.  SNAP, SNAP, SNAP, SN SNAP -- so quick, with great dexterity, though his face grimaces with the strength he has to exert with each application of pressure -- he cuts just as many links as knows he needs to push in a little flap of fence and roll under.  Whole thing accomplished in seconds.

dialogues.speaker: LOADING YARD
dialogues.text: Walks fast to the cover of the trucks.  Passes.  Looks around.  Cement loading docks and bays.  Shuttered doors. jumps up to one, puts his ear to the metal.  Listens awhi

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Scans the wall for any sign of an alarm box or anything. Then cocks an ear upwards... CAMERA CRANING UP to show us what he hears:  an air-conditioning unit HUMMING away.  W means someone must be inside. Wilson looks back at his entry options.  Not the loading doors -- but a conventional door at one end, with a conventional lock his eye zeroes in on.  Gets out his too going over. INT. WAREHOUSE HALLWAY. A SCRATCHING at the door.  It opens.  He's in. Waits.  Cautious.  Nothing.  He starts along the hallway. INT. WAREHOUSE. A SUPERVISOR (the one from the flash cuts) does a double as Wilson passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Wilson stops and turns.  Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walked. (coming over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for a bloke named Valentine. Know him? MEAT PUPPETS (who we saw before as well) who work here gathering.  The Supervisor and the Meat Puppets exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's expecting you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. The Supervisor moves toward Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why would he want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a message for him.  About Jennifer Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer Wilson. More looks are exchanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I know her, all right.  She came down here once, stirred up a shitstorm. We lost a full day's work, took me weeks to get back on schedule.  If she hadn't a' been Terry's woman I would've broke her jaw.  'Course, she's nobody's problem now. Wilson stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Valentine here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Wilson looks at the Meat Puppets, the loading area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, get the fuck out of here before you get hurt.  Who the fuck do you think you are, waltzing in here, asking questions? Wilson just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear me, asshole? The Supervisor shoves him.  The Meat Puppets move a littl anticipation.  Wilson isn't giving any indication that he going to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you really want your ass kicked, don't you? He pushes Wilson again, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, get outta here. He pushes Wilson again.  Still, Wilson won't leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' nut.  Go on. This time he tries to slap Wilson.  Wilson blocks the Supervisor's hand and then punches him, hard.  The Superv stumbles back and falls to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEAT PUPPETS
dialogues.text: Move to Wilson.  He tries to fend them off, but there are many.  They beat him.  When they find that he's armed, th beat him harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson is taken outside and dumped.  After a moment, he g to his feet.  Dusting himself.  Reaches for ANOTHER GUN t in his lower back.  He re-enters the building. A beat.  We hear several SHOTS. Seconds later, one of the Meat Puppets comes stumbling ou the door, terrified.  He runs past us, fast. A moment later, Wilson emerges, gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him.  You tell him I'm coming!!

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE. DUSK.
dialogues.text: A series of images that prove Valentine (whoever he is) h taste, wealth, and influence, stretching back a good thre decades at least. Walking through some of these shots is a young beauty in bathing suit named ADHARA.  She advances slowly, not enti sure of herself, and stops to look at things just like we At one point she looks to see a BEEFY GUY (GORDON) sittin the kitchen counter, flipping through a magazine.  He loo her up and down, more from reflex than anything. She continues on.  Eventually she emerges through sliding glass doors and on to a patio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figure by the pool, talking on the phone.  His back to The pool is spectacular, mosaic tile bottomed.

dialogues.speaker: ADHARA
dialogues.text: Approaches, then sits beside him.  His voice is soothing, with the tiniest hint of exasperation that comes with bei slightly ahead of everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not before.  Not before.  Think about it. What does it mean?  What -- no, I'm not. Think.  Yes.  See?  You figured it out all by yourself.  I know.  Are we done? Okay. He hangs up, stands, still doesn't turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adhara.  I told your father, if you're looking for a name, you can't go wrong with a constellation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to hate it.  Now I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be worse, he could've named you Reticulum. He turns and we see him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Polished.  Handsome.  Charismatic.  Especially when he's smiling like he is now.  He leans over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything in the world that you want or need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know why you need that scary guy in your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon?  He's been with me for years. He's not as tough as he looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what good is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible that you're too young to be acquainted with the idea of loyalty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for you, clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm loyal to things that make me happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're certainly not a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You're not specific enough to be a person.  You're more like a vibe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad we're having this chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an observation.  Like:  I'm hungry. When are we eating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as you get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything but Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not into finger foods.  Too fussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like do-it-yourself cuisine. Buffets.  Salad bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You demand to be served.  A fork fetishist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just fuel to me.  I'm not there for distractions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some, eating is a sensual experience. The sensual experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Gordon's always saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, god. His cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He listens, then looks up at his balcony, where a MAN (AV stands holding a phone, obviously talking to Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there as soon as I can. He hangs up. VALENTINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can leave as soon as you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. EXT. BALCONY.  EVENING. Valentine approaches Avery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been some trouble downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the papers used to call a "gangland slaying."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our black friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Terry.  They don't work like that. Jenny Wilson's father paid a little visit, left a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was in prison, in England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, either they have a very liberal work-release program, or he's out, because he's here in L.A., looking for you. Valentine is a little ruffled.  Maybe Avery likes that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wait, and we watch. Valentine just looks at him. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  POOLSIDE.  EVENING. Adhara approaches Valentine, who stands staring at the po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Italian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not who, food.  Should we get Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Turns to her. VALENTINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as I don't have to pass Gordon again.  I'm never ready for that. He smiles, rises, and offers her his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I know another way out. She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE on her way in.  Handsome woman.  Intelligent, capa looking.  Passes Wilson who's leaning somewhere smoking.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Aware as a wary woman will be of a strange man's presence without necessarily having looked at him.  Well aware too that he stayed where he was -- so she unworriedly unlocks building's security gate and goes through to the inner --

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: -- and closes the gate behind her, now seeing him amble u arriving as it CLICKS shut between them.  He's looking at a certain way.  She looks back.  And knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Jenny's father. And the recognition on his part:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a feeling it was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cigarette in hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it was the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not her brand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She used to pinch 'em off me. (trying to defuse Elaine's cold stare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny that.  One thing she never tried to get me to stop. Elaine doesn't soften.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanted to talk to you, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, why did you come here? America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort a few things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been busy, have you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was skint -- didn't have no money to get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you were -- what's that adorable phrase? -- "at Her Majesty's pleasure."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the bars, then. Indicating his face, viewed by Elaine through the barred security gate that divides them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In any case, I don't suppose the salary you make sewing mailbags is really commensurate with international airline travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sewing mailbags?  Me?  Never did an honest day's work in my life, dear. Wasn't about to start when I was in stir -- not with all that leisure time on my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not with all that buried loot you had waiting for you when you got out.  From the Wembley Staduim job, wasn't it?  Pink Floyd concert receipts.  Jenny would've been ... fourteen at the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to conceal his surprise)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly buried.  Earning interest, love. Earning interest in an offshore account. Tidy little premium per annum, that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that kind of security can't be bought.  Must be more comforting than a daughter to greet you. She turns to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, aren't you gonna let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try calling me again. INT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT.  EVENING. She comes in.  A modest studio apartment.  Puts her bag o the kitchenette countertop.  Glances at her answer machin see if she has any messages.  The phone RINGS.  She sits glumly on her couch, holds her head in her hands. EXT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT BUILDING.  EVENING. Wilson gives up, starts to walk away.  The gate BUZZES. INT. ELAINE'S APARTMENT.  EVENING. Elaine opens the door.  Wilson in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just going to toss some vegetable rolls in the microwave, open a can of diet soda. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to take me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson and Elaine at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... No, I went in for more improving pastimes.  Philosophy classes, language courses, European history, all that lark. Did you know that in Paris in the Eighteenth Century there were more rats in people's houses than there were people in people's houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like Beverly Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, are you always this sarky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarcastic, moi?  Maybe I'll mellow when my ship comes in.  It's expected any day now.  I'm all packed and ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't you on a television series?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has he seen it?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it played in England somebody owes me money.  Who told you that -- Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said it went on for donkey's years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three seasons.  They found that's the limit of human tolerance when it comes to following the adventures of a family of Mormons on the Chisum Trail. (blinks coquettishly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wife number three -- the ingenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it just ended, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who's being sarcastic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you've lost as many years as I have, love, puts things in perspective, know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I guess the rest of us have no excuse for wondering where the time went. (raises her drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must've been the bars. Their food arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a kind of prison, doing a series. Early to bed, early to rise, no time off for good behavior, you grab the boodle for as long as it lasts. (the kicker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only difference is you can't get arrested afterwards. Wilson appears fascinated by the cold glasses of water on table.  Ice cubes CLINKING as he holds his.  A BUSBOY bringing them to other people, too, just like that, witho anyone even asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe Jenny told you all that. About me.  She was always so embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ashamed. Wilson looks at her.  Okay.  What then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never told Eddie, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never told anyone else. (making light now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the convict strain -- or is it stain?  No, I was privileged.  I was someone who helped Jenny efface her past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you manage that, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm not honing my craft in episodic television I do double-duty as a voice coach.  Not that her accent would have hobbled her progress.  Not with that look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, she started all that in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learnin' 'ow to speak proper. (putting it on a bit there. Then, upper crust:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Central School of Speech and Drama. It's no doddle gettin' in there, y'know. At seventeen.  They offered her a place at RADA n' all, only she'd've had to wait till the next session and she was always in hurry to get on, was Jenny.  She could talk posh without any training, when she was knee-high to a grasshopper. (indicating himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show up the old man, you know. Elaine smiles slightly.  None of this information new to But warming to this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't disappointed in her, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Jenny?  'Course not.  How could I be. 'Course I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was twenty-one when she came to me. (looks at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Straight from leaving you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footloose and fancy free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was happy here.  However the two of you might have parted.  Don't think she wasn't. It's because Wilson thinks the opposite that he's here. Looks at Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the trouble, n' it. (hard as nails again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enjoyed life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along the seafront.  We HEAR the ocean but can' see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.  Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (occurs to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been lurking outside my building all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I had -- some other matters to attend to, you know.  Getting a car sorted ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might've been away for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I reckoned, Saturday night, if you were goin' out, you'd probably have to come home first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've seen Eddie Rama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, saw Eddie, yeah.  Me and him are muckers. Mates.  Friends.  Makes a kind of bonding gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should really give him a call.  He's a character, isn't he.  Well, not to you. I meant to us squares in the outside world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He give me your address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him yours.  Said, here, you want to write, I think this is a relative.  I guess I thought I was being true to Jenny.  Who told me she didn't have a father -- before proceeding of course to tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't suppose she did, really, most of her life.  On her own after her mum died.  Aunts and uncles for a time -- and then the bright lights beckoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you still married at the time -- to Jenny's mother, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, we split up when Jenny was six.  Her second husband done a runner after she got sick.  They give me compassionate leave from Parkhurst to go visit her in hospital.  We were always mates, me and Jenny's mum.  I like to think they're together again now.  Y'know.  Heavenly choir. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The address Jenny gave me, that wasn't a prison, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, accommodation address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, like a P.O. box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you get your bank statements. Wilson gives a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you gotta have something permanent, don'tcha.  Even if it's a hole in the wall.  No matter which jug I might be transferred to, I always got someone on the out checks up on it for me, see. Anything I need to know, comes round on visitor's day -- word in my ear. Elaine pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some word. Wilson leans on the wall overlooking the black ocean.  So of WAVES gently lapping the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already knew.  Knew beforehand.  When was it supposed to have happened? -- two o'clock in the morning, Eddie said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what was estimated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hours difference between here and London.  Would've been, what, ten in the morning, my time.  I was just coming out on the yard.  Now, I was in the habit of saving my newspaper till then.  Bit of fresh air, stretch me legs -- well, stretch the day out, really, that's what you wanna do.  And I'll tell ya:  I couldn't open the paper.  Could not pry the pages apart -- it was like they was glued together.  That's how weak my hands went.  Thought I was having heart attack, only I knew I wasn't.  Bloke come up to me, he says, Dave, he says, you've gone all white.  I said, fuck me, I've been in prison half my life, what d'ya expect. But he was dead on, 'cause I could feel the blood drain right out of me head. And I knew ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something had happened to Jen. They stand here a while.  Listening to the BREAKERS hit t shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home.  Steal something. That gets her a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing I can't afford to lose. She goes to make coffee.  Wilson looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even know who Terry Valentine is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I gathered something from the article what Eddie sent me.  Some sort of pop music producer, wasn't it. Maybe a smile from Elaine at the quaintness of "pop" musi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock n' roll, is what we called it. He's sort of a forgotten figure now, but back when the West Coast was the grooviest place on earth, Terry Valentine was where all the happenings happened. More of a kind of promoter, I guess, whatever that means. Just took that whole Southern California Sixties Zeitgeist and ran with it. Packaged and sold it. Made out like a bandit. FLASH CUTS: VALENTINE. At home. Watching as Adhara undresses, either deliberately for him, or just casually. She smiles as she notices he's looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he done lately. That line pregnant with meaning.  Elaine looks at him. Avoids answering the question actually implied there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brings a tray over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lives high off the hog and waits for the next big thing.  Like me -- but on a grander scale of failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you shouldn't run yourself down.  My employer, Mr. Lindgren --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Your employer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mr. Lindgren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Mr. Lindgren?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My employer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What line is he in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proprietor of a London firm.  Of longstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based in London, but with international concerns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various enterprises, style of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said you never did an honest day's work in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not to say Mr. Lindgren is dishonest, exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she gets the picture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyhow, he's always saying to me, Dave, never run yourself down, son -- 'cause there'll always be plenty of people willing to do it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what capacity are you employed by this Mr. Lindgren?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This and that.  Y'know.  Ways and means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- When he wants someone run down, you're willing to do it for him. They sort of come together -- in mutual understanding -- sit down.  Coffee steaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the deal.  You and Terry Valentine at twenty paces.  Is that what this is about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever known me not to be. Elaine looks away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuckin' guys and your dicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you want me to do.  Stay at home, twiddlin' me thumbs.  Doing sweet F.A. [Fuck All].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe it was a car accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry's never going to give you satisfaction.  Not the type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends, don' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what.  What makes you so certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bloody well ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the phone.  You want his number.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: That look again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got his number.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Past caring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to help you. She goes into a bathroom.  Shutting the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Sips coffee.  Bites into a cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thickets part and we SEE Wilson scrambling up a rather st hill.  Coming to a ridge where he settles down to look at something O.S.  His expression changes by degrees from curiosity to dawning realization to a kind of frustrated disappointment. INT. WILSON'S CAR (ON THE ROAD BELOW).  LATE AFTERNOON. Ed sits in here, RADIO on.  Wilson appears out of the bru gets in.  Ed turns the radio down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mindful of the odd car driving past)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you you wouldn't be able to see through that gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gate's open.  I had a butcher's at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you butcher at the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butcher's hook.  Look. (doesn't anyone speak English in this fucking country?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't much reckon those minders of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's brought in the heavy mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extra muscle.  Bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look a right load of wallies. Patrolling back and forth outside the gate, all ponced up like the fuckin' Household Cavalry. (ducks suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it. As one of the "bodyguards" runs by, only fleetingly glimp by us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was one of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits up again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean?  Wearing bloomin' uniforms n' all. Off Ed's perplexed look ... EXT. HILLSIDE UNDERBRUSH.  LATE AFTERNOON. Wilson settles into position again, this time with Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. Ed just laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so fucking funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't guards.  They're valets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we SEE what Wilson had mistaken for Valentine's priva army.  Half a dozen VALETS outside Valentine's hilltop ho Dressed in matching attire, a couple of them wielding wal talkies.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME WILSON AND ED
dialogues.text: Ed's still laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valets.  What d'ya mean valets.  What is he, then, the Earl of fucking Doncaster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valets.  They park cars.  He's having a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson's car pulls up.  He and Ed get out.  Wilson engage a mini tug-of-war with a Valet over his car key, it so ru him the wrong way having to give it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it handy, mate, all right?  We're not stopping long. He gestures, apparently getting the message across that h wants the car kept close by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. Exchanges the key for a card -- which he turns over in hi hand and studies curiously as they head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valets, eh?  Aren't we all la-de-da.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous being here)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you just wanted to check out the house, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's what we're doin', n' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one else is even here yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First in, first out, that's me. Looking over to note the multi-car GARAGE off the main ho INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  AFTERNOON. Wilson and Ed are among the first to arrive.  A smatterin other GUESTS.  Elaborate catered cuisine.  They mosey ove the wet bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen.  What can I get you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suggesting Ed take first crack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dubonnet with a twist?  Baby sham? Tomato juice and Tabasco sauce? By now his whole dynamic with Ed is a verbal tease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bartender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a Coke? INT. VALENTINE'S BEDROOM.  AFTERNOON. Valentine is checking himself in a full-length mirror.  T in background, sound low (ENTERTAINMENT WEEK!).  Not quit satisfied, Valentine crosses to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Valentine takes one more closer look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the same posters. Valentine turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: ADHARA
dialogues.text: Is lounging in the large tub.  Staring dreamily at a coup of framed posters on the walls:  more 60's psychedelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you have down at your office. Valentine sits on the edge of the tub.  With a nostalgic as he looks at her:  the embodiment of youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different ones. He strokes her wet skin.  They kiss lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the colors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must've been a time.  A golden moment. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever dreamed of a place ... you don't really recall ever having been to ... a place that probably doesn't even exist except in your imagination ... somewhere far away, half-remembered when you wake up ... but when you were there you spoke the language, you knew your way around ... (significant pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the 60's. With that exit line (practiced?), he starts to go. Then pauses, turns again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't.  Wasn't either. Comes back to her.  Faraway look in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was '66 ... early '67. (comes back to now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was all. He goes. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS HALLWAY.  AFTERNOON. Wilson wanders around, exploring the house.  Comes to a w of photographes.  Casually scanning them as he passes slo by, he's caught up short by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A framed photo of JENNY, his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: A series of emotions play over his face.  He turns -- SEE Valentine coming down the stairs.  Valentine joins the pa without noticing him.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE BUFFET TABLE
dialogues.text: Ed peruses the available food.  Valentine comes over to c it out.  Glances at Ed without recognizing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. And goes away.  Leaving Ed more nervous than ever. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  UPSTAIRS HALLWAY.  AFTERNOON. Wilson has come up here.  Peeks into one room.  Moves alo another:  the master bedroom.  Opens the door gently. INT. MASTER BATHROOM. Adhara is still enjoying her bath. INT. MASTER BEDROOM. Wilson enters.  Careful.  Aware that someone's in the adj bathroom.  The soft RIPPLE of WATER from in there.  Perha even glimpses her through the door as he boldly looks aro He notices a video camera on a tripod, a cord running to television.  Suddenly we hear the CHIRP of a cellular pho

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Adhara reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. She gets out of the tub and goes for the nearest towel. Quickly wrapping herself, she exits.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Adhara enters and goes for her purse.  She pulls the RING phone out and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Hey!  Great.  You got my message? Yeah.  No, Crestview Terrace, not Crestview Place.  Yeah, there's like three different ways up the hill; the quick way is to bear to the right.  Sure.  Okay. Okay.  'Bye! She hangs up and begins toweling her hair.  After a momen she stops.  Something isn't right.  She looks around the room, and her eyes stop on the TV.  Her brow furrows, try to place the familiar image on the screen:  a girl towel- drying her hair by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. She looks over to see the video camera, which has been tu on and pointed toward the bed.  She's not sure if it's fu or creepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine mingling, all smiles and movement.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: At the foot of the stairs.  Watches him, all stillness an intensity.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Catches Wilson's eye for a nanosecond, does a subtle doub take, then moves on. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  UPSTAIRS HALLWAY.  AFTERNOON. Adhara, dressed, looking great, exits the bedroom and hea for the stairwell. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Adhara descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Turning to SEE her as she comes down.

dialogues.speaker: ADHARA
dialogues.text: Makes her way across the room to Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I thought you weren't a buffet person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a gracious host.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Watching them, when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Wilson looks at him.  Reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you work with Ian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could swear I met you with Ian at the EMI offices in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  Wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless I'm not who I think I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.  Ian's got a good thing going over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turned that place completely around.  180 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I like about Ian, he believes in a chain of command, but not a chain of respect, you understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Chain of respect.  That's good, that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I really admire the guy.  Well. Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Cheers, mate. The Guy leaves.  Wilson sees that Adhara is now on the ot side of the room, separated from Valentine.  He heads for her.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Still dealing with people desperate to be the focus of hi attention.  He notices:

dialogues.speaker: WILSON AND ADHARA
dialogues.text: Talking in a corner.  She seems attentive.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: In a SERIES OF CUTS, still being the gracious host, still keeping his eyes on:

dialogues.speaker: WILSON AND ADHARA
dialogues.text: Who, in a SERIES OF CUTS, continue to talk.  Finally, the separate, Wilson heading outside onto a deck.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Excuses himself from a group of sycophants and goes to he

dialogues.speaker: ADHARA
dialogues.text: Valentine approaches and begins talking to her, low.  Aft few moments of conversation, they both look toward:

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: On the deck outside.  Joining Ed, who's taken refuge out with a plate of food.  What Wilson can't belleve when he it -- is that behind Valentine's house, which is on top o high hill, is nothing but desolate scrub canyon.  On the side of the railing around the deck, which is surely less than regulation height, is a sheer drop into an abyss. WILSON (cont'd) (jumps back with only slightly affected vertigo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flipping heck. Ed, a little more accustomed to L.A. architecture, nods i agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could afford a house like this you would buy a house like this. Wilson edges forward to the rail again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we standing on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith. They stand there looking out.  Quite a view once you get to it.  Breeze. ED (cont'd) (nods to the hazy distance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could see the sea from here if you could see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you? But now Ed gives Wilson a nudge -- SEEING that Valentine inside the house is making his way out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go nick one of those little cooker what's its warming up the sausages cocktail and meet me in the garage.  Look about for a toolbox while you're at it. Ed considers.  His is not to reason why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Ed moves off.  Valentine steps up, smile fully loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  Terry Valentine. He extends his hand.  Wilson shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we met?  There's something I can't quite --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMI in London.  I work with Ian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must know Ian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great bloke.  Really turned things around there.  180 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose that's good, unless things were fine the way they were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I think a shake-up was in order. Definitely.  Otherwise, people get lazy, don't they?  Forgetful.  Start thinking they can get away with things.  Gotta shake 'em up now and again, make 'em pay attention. Wilson looks at him.  Valentine looks back.  Something ab those eyes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, Terry ... The Excited Guy appears, tugging at Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad I got to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ter ... Ter ... you gotta ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  You, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be seein' you. The Excited Guy ushers Valentine away.  Wilson watches hi go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Grodin is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, waiting.  Wilson enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it? Ed displays the Sterno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toolbox? Ed points to a table, where a toolbox sits.  Wilson cross to it, begins going through the contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the Sterno on the ground, near the center of the garage. Ed does.  Wilson pulls a brace-and-bit from the toolbox a crosses to the rear of one of the cars.  Dropping to the ground, he bores a hole in the gas tank.  Ed raises his eyebrows and moves toward the door.  Wilson crosses to th other car and puts a hole in that gas tank as well.  Then puts the brace-and-bit back in the toolbox and heads for exit, Ed right behind him, giving a quick backward glance

dialogues.speaker: THE GASOLINE
dialogues.text: Spills out, slowly but steadily, and slithers toward the garage door. EXT. BETWEEN VALENTINE'S HOUSE AND GARAGE.  AFTERNOON. Wilson and Ed walk briskly along the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives Ed parking ticket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring the motor around.  Bang out in front, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goin' back inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I need. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Valentine is talking to Gordon, his beefy bodyguard, and looking around.  He stops as he sees Wilson once again stepping onto the deck.  He points Wilson out to Gordon, nods and heads for the deck. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  AFTERNOON. Ed hands the ticket to a Valet.  He exchanges looks with couple of the other Valets. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  DOWNSTAIRS.  AFTERNOON. Valentine is talking to Adhara, who is introducing her Girlfriend.  As Valentine greets her, he glances outside where Gordon is approaching Wilson on the deck. EXT. DECK. Wilson SEES Gordon approaching.  Gets ready to greet him. Removes cigarette from mouth, drops it to floor of deck, presses it out under his shoe.  Limbers up his shoulders subtle way. Gordon coming towards him.  As if to challenge Wilson's legitimacy as an invited guest.  Closer.  About to speak. But Wilson doesn't even give him a chance to do that.  In quick succession:  Wilson HEAD BUTTS Gordon, splintering nose; KNEES him in the groin; then, using the knee for leverage, grabs Gordon by the lapels -- and heaves him ov the railing! It happened so fast that if anyone else is nearby they probably didn't even notice -- or didn't readily grasp wh they saw. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE. Valentine had turned his attention back to Adhara and her Girlfriend.  When he glances back to the deck he's a litt concerned not to see Gordon anywhere out there anymore -- just Wilson coming back in.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Adjusting his jacket, walking back through the house.  Be him, people are rushing to the railing and looking over. few yells of "Call an ambulance!" etc. are heard.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Moves that way.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Moving across the room towards the front door.  They are heading right toward each other.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON AND VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Pass each other, eyes locked, almost dream-like.  Wilson' eyes cold, though with the hint of a smile.  Valentine th a last look back before reaching the deck. EXT. DECK. Valentine pushes through to look over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon -- a crumpled, inert heap way down the hill below.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Turns to look toward the front door.  Wilson not to be se Valentine pushes through the crowd toward the door. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  AFTERNOON. Valentine emerges in time to see Ed and Wilson pulling aw Wilson looks at him, impassive, through the passenger win

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Is just arriving in his car.  Valentine gestures at him. Suddenly we HEAR a loud, bass-heavy WHHUUUMMMPPP. Valentine (and a few others) turn toward the sound, which came from:

dialogues.speaker: THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: There is smoke coming from under the door. EXT. CANYON ROAD.  AFTERNOON. Wilson's car practically tobogganing back down the hill. BOOM!  We hear an explosion from back UP the hill. INT. WILSON'S CAR. Ed jumps -- though he's driving.  The gas pedal his most pressing concern.  Negotiating the dangerously winding ro comes second.  Exhilaration mixed with panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You steady on, man.  What the fuck else did you do back there. EXT. ROAD. An especially sharp curve looms ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Flinches, grabs a handhold.

dialogues.speaker: CURVE
dialogues.text: Car makes it around on two side wheels.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. Ed regains control.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: In his car, takes a different turn. EXT. ROAD.  CAR. Swerves some more curves.  Should be some sense here that similar skyline route would have been taken by Wilson's daughter on her final drive. INT. WILSON'S CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you just kill him, you had the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be too easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too easy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gotta know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think a fuckin' guy like that ever will?  What more do you want, man? Suddenly out of nowhere -- (a side street) -- BAM! -- ano car shoots out to cut them off, sideswiping them. EXT. ROAD. Wilson's car SKIDS into a spin from the impact.

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER CAR
dialogues.text: It's Avery.  Chased them via a shortcut down the mountain Now jumps out of his car, levels a shotgun at them and pu off a BLAST.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON'S CAR
dialogues.text: BAM! -- the trunk pops open as the car rights itself.  Av FIRES again, but the upended trunk is a kind of shield, deflecting the shot. INT. WILSON'S CAR. Despite the fact that Ed is still in the driver's seat (a managed rather skillfully to avoid crashing) -- Wilson ac like he's not there, grabs the steering wheel, jams the c into reverse, virtually sitting on Ed as he pounds his ow foot onto the gas pedal -- and with his ferocious eyes monitoring the door-mirror, steamrolls the car backwards towards Avery. EXT. ROAD. Wilson reverses his car like a speeding tank:  SMASHING i Avery's car.  Pushing it right off the edge of the road.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Falls backwards to the ground as he gets the hell out of way.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Jumps out of his car.  Gun drawn.  Advancing on Avery wit pointed.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY'S CAR
dialogues.text: CRASHING through underbrush down the steep bank of the hillside.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON'S FACE
dialogues.text: SOUND of the divebombing car OVER.  Another pointed echo his daughter's fate.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet momentarily.  And before Wilson can shoot Avery rolls over the edge of the road himself.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Calls frantically to Wilson from their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, man!  C'mon! SIRENS in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: That consuming rage overtaken him again for a second.  Bu the exigencies of the moment snap him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Turns on a dime, goes back to the car.  Before he's halfw in, Ed's driving them away again.  Trunk at the back BANG up and down, up and down.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Pulls himself back up to the road.  Brushing himself off. Looking the way they went. He gently tosses his shotgun down into some thick brush w maybe he'll retrieve it later. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  AFTERNOON. Avery returns, sweating, walking back up the road to wher all the action is.  Party guests milling outside, waiting their cars so they can leave.  A fire truck, a police car SMOKE pouring out of Valentine's garage. Valentine finishes talking to a couple of COPS.  Walks ov Avery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have let me do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, because you're my security consultant? (insecure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This cocksucker nearly burnt my house down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more concerned about police presence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you tell them. Valentine blows air, runs a hand through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them a long-time employee flipped out.  Had a drug problem, refused counselling.  Set the garage on fire, then committed suicide.  One of my "guests" tried to stop him -- but how do you stop Gordon. In this context meaning how did that rangy Englishman do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, Gordon must weigh a good four hundred pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavier than that now.  But are there any drugs in that stomach to back up your story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it happens.  I didn't make that part up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where is this guest?  Don't they want to interview him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know everyone here.  He was so traumatized he split. (another notion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he was Gordon's pusher. Avery stares at Valentine.  Impressed at him thinking on feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think he is, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I mean.  Not even your people should be involved.  Right?  It's too close now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could use a few of my prime shitkickers up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's already gonna be talk about how people close to you keep falling into canyons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, can we make it one more.  Nowhere the fuck near me. He's being glib, but he's being serious.  His open-handed gesture inquiring of Avery:  are you up to the task?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have other resources. He turns to go. EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE.  CANYON.  AFTERNOON. The huge dead bulk of Gordon hoisted back up to the deck paramedic team. INT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE. Valentine comes back in.  In the living room beyond, Adha stands anxiously, where she's been waiting for him.  Cops visible outside on the deck, peering over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Heading that way.  Then stops.  Backtracks.  Something peripherally had caught his eye and he returns to it.  Hi wall of photographs.

dialogues.speaker: AN EMPTY FRAME
dialogues.text: The one that had contained the picture of Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safely down the hill.  Driving away in traffic, Ed calmer now.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Pulls the rolled-up photograph of his daughter out of his jacket and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two characters stand, leaning, against a back wall.  Star ahead, without purpose.  Halfheartedly watching a game of pool in progress.  Just hanging out.
