Strange, threatenin characters.  One of them is young.  Lean, hungry-looking. STACY is his name.  A shrewd, scheming kid.  But definite little unhinged.  Weirder is his companion.  UNCLE JOHN. title isn't one of courtesy.  He's an actual blood relati Maybe 25 years older than Stacy.  But intellectually youn Physically, much bigger.  The man is huge.  Nevertheless, safer of the two -- until Stacy tells him otherwise.  Way they're standing next to each other suggests the ease the feel in each other's company.  Tight bond.  They're good buddies.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Walks in.  Stops to look around.  Spots his two freaks. Walks toward them.

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: A mysterious black man has followed Avery in.  THOMPSON i his name.  He hangs back and watches.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Makes contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy. Stacy turns to see him.  Uncle John looks vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bored)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over here. That was in the way of an order.  He nods around the corn where it's less crowded.  Stacy stops Uncle John from following, and goes after Avery.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: At the bar.  Keeping his eye on them.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Speaks softly.  Alone with Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How they goin', kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Opens it.  Elaine has come to visit.  Lets her in.  After closing the door resumes his position on the bed. Elaine looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the neighborhood.  I come down here quite a bit.  Watch the planes taking off. (re this motel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Study the architecture of early David Lynch. But she doesn't really have it in her to be ironic right Leans back against the door. Wilson remains silent.  He's done the same to Elaine now he did to Ed.  Almost magically induced her to a confessi verge. Elaine, too, isn't sure she wants to be complicit in this revenge tragedy.  But here goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny was supposed to come to my place that night.  She called me, asked if she could come over.  She and Terry had been -- having some trouble.  Lately.  I don't know about what.  On this occasion, it reached some sort of crisis point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told you all about my details but not about his.  Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd never called me like that before. She sounded more ... pissed off -- angry -- than upset or afraid.  But she never turned up.  I called the house but only got the answer machine.  When they found her ... she'd been going the wrong way. Not the direction she'd have gone if she'd been coming to see me.  Or coming straight to see me.  Who knows.  Maybe she just wanted to drive. She looks at Wilson.  Shrugs.  That's it.  That's all.  I it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (measured)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you come to have my address? Found it, did you.  Among her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Terry gave me access to her things?  Probably sold her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently urging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how did you get it? Elaine looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gave me your address. Wilson nods. ELAINE (cont'd) (starting to realize)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long before ... (realizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said if anything ever happened ... (realizes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how you know.  That's why you're so sure. (realization)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny's telling you. She's sitting on the bed now.

dialogues.text: Stacy, putting on a jacket that says "Bomb Hanoi" comes o of the pool hall.  Uncle John in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taps pocket)

dialogues.text: I got half.

dialogues.text: Makin' trouble for someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THEM
dialogues.text: Thompson, the mysterious black man, watches them from the hall doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early. INT. WILSON'S ROOM. Wilson and Elaine.  Getting dressed.  She's in pantyhose. Fastening a bra.  He's got trousers on, reaching for a sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long've you lived here? Elaine sits on the bed, fastening her skirt.  Her bra str cuts across her bare back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This town's been chewing my flesh since ... what we now refer to as "the early 70's." (thinks back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, my past became nostalgia and no one even asked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early 70's.  I was away. (tries to remember)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maidstone.  Possibly Brixton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These more highlights from the Zagat prison guide? Wilson looks at her:  she's the one who goes to bed with cons.

dialogues.text: You don't seem bothered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know how I've compromised my standards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too involved; a lifetime of non- involvement.  Anywhere else I'd be an interesting little number, here I'm just SAG number forty-eight thousand and one. (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAG meaning Screen Actor's Guild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I was gonna say ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, there have been rewards.  It's sunny.  And some of the producers who call even have credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see the attraction. She glances up at him to try and see how he means that. he looking at her or out the window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?  To make them take the early 70's away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jeweller's up the West End.  We tunnelled our way under the shop floor from the public lavatory down the road. Filthy work.  Trouble was, the bloody thing collapsed -- after we'd made the grab, 'n all.  Would you Adam n' Eve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean if they'd nabbed you before you actually broke and entered you would only have been charged with making a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were lucky to be nicked.  Me and the lads went down there Sunday evening, we weren't discovered till the Monday.  Good job we were still breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't discourage you, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From pursuing your chosen profession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell ya something:  it made me a model prisoner.  Put me right off any escape attempts.  Tunnel my way to freedom after that experience?  Not bloody likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was inside once.  I punched a cop at a demo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you.  What was that in aid of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get seven years, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overnight.  What about just now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now? (playful, goes over, ready for more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overnight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been away. (lies back, regards him carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is all this just new to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.  Has to be said.  I got off to a slow start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest.  Didn't know where to look till I was 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing the legal limit even then. He stands again, vaguely disappointing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me mate introduced me to a woman up the street.  Funnily enough, she was married to a milkman.  Straight up.  I said, "Good is she?  Been around?"  He said, "Good?  Listen, mush, it's not that she's been around, it's that she's been around hell of a long time." He laughs uproariously at that.  But the point is:  he's of complimenting both Elaine and himself.  They've been around, had their knocks, they've lasted.  Elaine remains unsmiling. Still leaning back on her elbows on the bed, in bra, skir hose, no shoes.  She asks again the question Wilson avoid answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your most recent incarceration.  What was that for? And again he evades the answer she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was for nine years. (buttoning his shirt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, we see the Pacific coastline.  Impres And a sleek Italian sports car.  Heading north. INT. SPORTS CAR. Valentine at the wheel.  Adhara besides him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lived in L.A. all my life, I've never done this drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All your life.  That happened while I swam the length of my pool. Adhara looks back over her shoulder.  Checking the road behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  I guess it's hard to pass on this road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freeway's faster, but lacks a certain majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just feels like the car behind has been following us the longest time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure hope so. INT. THE CAR BEHIND. A big utility vehicle.  With Avery in the front passenger seat.  And three bodyguards he's brought along to protect Valentine.  RICK driving, TOM and LARRY in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I'm sayin' is travel time shouldn't be the same rate.  Travel time is down time, right?  I mean, we're not even in the same car as the client. (to Avery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me the job was at the house. When we get to it.  Well, are we shadowing the client right now or are we just going the same way?  The company I was with in Seattle, these distinctions were made. Now, I don't dispute him getting the full whack. (he means Rick, who's older)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seniority and all that.  But if I'm getting paid the same hourly rate when we're at the house as I am in this car, that doesn't sit well with me and I feel obliged to say so.  'Cause in Seattle what you're paying now for so-called travel time was half what we got for actual clock-time with the client.  So I just feel we should get more when the job actually commences. After this spineless whining weak-willed sob story, Larry just turns to him and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'd really like to eat your pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy and Uncle John sitting on a bench in a beach settin (though we still don't see the ocean).  Or on some grass, maybe, in a little park -- opposite Elaine's building. People-watching.  In their own unique way.  Stacy comment on fellow humanity all around them.  TIME CUTS between ea comment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after laughing loudly at a handicapped person)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in mocking the afflicted.  Good for 'em.  Makes 'em stronger. Uncle John picks at the grass or sand.  As they kill the

dialogues.text: (spotting a woman with a dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (barely out of earshot of a black woman with dyed blonde hair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very attractive.  Good idea.  Now I really want to fuck you.

dialogues.text: (after a long time in silence, just staring at someone)

dialogues.text: (sitting up)

dialogues.text: "Homeless" people.  Fuck them.  Remember when they were just bums?  Everyone with an axe to grind.  Like to grind in their face.  Pretty soon there'll be shit-in- your-pants rights groups.  Stupidity activists.

dialogues.text: I'd love to be famous so I could snub ordinary people.  Imagine, you're famous, you're sitting in a restaurant, some fool comes up to you, wants you to sign your name on his napkin, his wife is there, it would be something these poor saps would cherish the rest of their lives, talk about to their cretin friends.  Bam!  You tell 'em to FUCK OFF!  God, I'd love that. Suddenly Uncle John speaks.

dialogues.text: Across the street, Elaine comes out of her building.  (We supposing this is an apartment building somewhat worth li in that has outdoor parking of some kind, visible from th street, or only street parking.)

dialogues.text: Elaine's car on the move.  Stacy and Uncle John in a car following. INT. ELAINE'S CAR. Going somewhere.  Unaware of the creeps in her wake. INT. STACY/UNCLE JOHN'S CAR. An "8x10" of Elaine on their back seat.  Another picture her on a page torn from a "Player's Directory."

dialogues.text: (driving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any happier than any other asshole in life. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: On screen:  A BEAUTIFUL MODEL -- but speaking in ELAINE'S VOICE.

dialogues.text: At a mic.  Wearing headphones.  Matching her voice to the model's lip movements.  Looping this commercial or whatev it is. INT. HALLWAY. Wilson.  Comes to a window where he can see Elaine inside the sound-proofed studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- they want Southern, I do Southern, they want Midwest, I do Midwest, they want tall, blonde, and twenty-two, I'm shit out of luck. (pauses)

dialogues.text: One thing I can't do is English. Americans can't.  Shouldn't even try. And Laurence Olivier couldn't do us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: So, is there anybody in your family who's not a criminal?

dialogues.text: Not that I recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your grandmother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah -- she was married to me grandad -- he was as bent as a boomerang -- used to make knuckle-dusters down the shop. Crafty old sod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black market during the war. Elaine shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you're just habitual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like my fucking probation officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't he be looking for you about now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck to him.  He couldn't find his prick if he didn't wear Y-fronts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minor officials bother you, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do us a favor.  Can't even go have a slash without 'em saying, what're you going in there for? EXT. ELAINE'S BUILDING.  DAY. Elaine and Wilson enter.  Stacy not far behind.  Catches outside gate before it slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson and Elaine turn the corner into the corridor approaching her apartment door.  Pause to kiss.  Walk clo And Stacy appears at the other end of the hall.  Both arm stretched out with the .38 at the end of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, kids. Starts to squeeze off a shot.  As Wilson pushes Elaine to floor.  As another SHOT rings out from further along the behind Stacy.  Catching him across the cheek.  Only skimm him.  But knocking him down.  Bullet chipping the wall.

dialogues.text: Across from Stacy.  Freezes, his own gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Three BLACK GUYS.  Including Thompson.  They approach.  G pointed at Stacy and Uncle John.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Hand on his .45 now.  But a fourth Black Guy coming up be him.  Wilson lowers the .45.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Flattened herself back against a wall.  Petrified.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Sits on the floor.  Holds his hurt face.  Thompson walks and picks up Stacy's gun.  One of the other blacks reliev reluctant Uncle John of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops at Wilson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with us. If there's any doubt whether Wilson will -- one of the bl gently puts the muzzle of a gun to Elaine's head.  Cocks hammer. They all go off down the stairwell.  Except Stacy and Unc John. Hit men wondering what hit them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Wilson's motel room, another version of a cell. A small window, high up.  Bricks and debris around the fl And Wilson and Elaine.  Sitting, leaning against opposite stone walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me you wouldn't prefer a steady income. Wilson takes a cigarette pack from a pocket.  Lights hims one.  Then tosses the stuff over to Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a steady income -- I'm on the dole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lights up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A leech on the welfare state in addition. You don't miss a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fiddle it.  They got me down as an immigrant with five kids. Elaine sort of shares a laugh at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... Jenny spoke fondly of her imaginary siblings. Though real ones might have been nice.  This an unspoken thought between them. ELAINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the last time you saw her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time might as well've been the first.  I remember all the times, don't I.  Watching her grow up -- (finding the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in increments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me you were a ghost in her life. Daddy the friendly ghost.  Coming back to haunt her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she twigged by the time she was eight or nine that daddy wasn't in the Royal Marines or doing scientific research in the jungles of Borneo or playing Iago in a worldwide tour of OTHELLO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, you could never ... do what she wanted. Wilson shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She used to tell me she'd turn me in. (tries to laugh about it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little kid.  Ten year old.  "If you're naughty, Dad, I'll tell on ya."  She didn't want me sent down again, see. When I was planning some job.  "I'll tell 'em, Dad, I promise I will.  Here, look, I'm calling the Old Bill right now" -- picking up the telephone.  I can see her, the phone in her hand.  Became a sort of joke between us.  Only it wasn't a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never would have turned you in, not in a million years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.  But as time went on ... well, it wasn't a joke, was it?  She had a feeling about it -- about the last job -- how long I'd get the hook for.  Said she wouldn't be there this time when I got out. DOOR opens.  Thompson.  Gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson leads Wilson past a row of windows.  Dockyards, harbor activity outside.  Toward a door with things stencilled on it.  One of them:  US DEPT. OF CUSTOMS. INT. OFFICE. A man named FEATHER.  Black.  Half sitting on the edge of table.  Wilson is shown in. Wilson at the door.  Sizes Feather up at a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where I come in. He walks confidently in.  Outside, through the window, an image of a foreign sports car being hoisted in the air by crane. There's a chair.  Wilson sits in it. Feather squints a little.  Seems ready to listen to whate Wilson has to say. WILSON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going, squire, all right?  Now listen -- when I was in the nick -- second time, it was -- no, third.  Third stretch, yeah.  There was this screw had it in for me.  That geezer was top of my list.  Two years after I was slung, I saw him.  He was sitting on a bench in Holland Park.  There was no one else about.  I coulda gone up behind him and snapped his fucking neck.  But I left it. Coulda nobbled him, but I didn't.  'Cos what I thought I wanted wasn't what I wanted.  What I thought I was thinking about was something else.  This berk on the bench wasn't worth my time.  See what I mean?  It didn't matter.  It meant sod all in the end. Feather has been listening to this, expressionless.  Now raises a finger as if there's a point he wants clarified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one thing I don't understand. (wants to make this clear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing I don't understand ... is every motherfucking thing you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, mush, you're the guv'nor here, I can see that, I'm on your manor now, right.  So there's no need to get out of your pram.  I'm Johnny-come-lately to all this.  Whatever the bollocks between you and this slag Valentine, it's got nothing to do with me.  I don't wanna know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you.  I believe this Valentine screwed me out of a fair sum of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can well believe it.  I'm sure he has done, son.  He's about as straight as a dog's hind leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't be sure.  I don't even know who he is.  He's too insulated.  Too many layers around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your guess is as good as mine, mate.  I'm here on another matter entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves to window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good job your lot showed up when they did or it would've been me for the high jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That dude who works for Valentine.  He's the one sent those guys after you.  You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Shouldn't wonder.  Must've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's your beef, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing financial.  Strictly personal. (moves to window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see how all this import-export malarkey might give rise to confusion where I'm concerned.  A foreigner, showing up unexpectedly, like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you.  Downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all innocent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that wasn't anything to do with me.  And suspicion has been cast in my direction. (pondering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't make any sense.  Choosing those shitheads over me, cutting me out of the deal, then screwing them over too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can reassure you on that point. Valentine was just as surprised by that turn of events as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd already grabbed more than his allotted cut.  Didn't think he'd be so bold as to take all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the deal, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, right.  The deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you're mad at him too and he's mad at you ... that must make us pals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you prefer, squire.  As you prefer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary of his life)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In which case I'll just do what I usually do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing? He's standing at the window, staring out.  As if Wilson i even in the room any more.  A ship being loaded out there Inspectors with clipboards.  Trucks like the ones we saw that warehouse downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking the other way. (turns to go)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along the way up the coast. Through a window we SEE Valentine and Adhara enjoying a pleasant lunch. The bodyguards hang out by the cars outside with fast foo bags and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, how much are you getting?  Just as a point of interest.  See, I didn't realize there was a sliding scale.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: At a payphone.  His idiots in the background.  Dials a number. INT. POOL HALL.  DAY. Stacy.  Nasty bruise on his cheek.  Takes a cue off the r Chalks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight rotation, no shit, call your shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme break. They're playing against a couple of other creeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You broke last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him break - he likes to break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your mother on the Strip last night.  She went up to three guys, said she'd like 'em to stick one in each, know what I mean? Creep rushes Stacy.  But doesn't get past Uncle John.  Wh drops him with one punch.  Flooring him between two pool tables.  Stacy then goes over.  Supports himself with a h on each table, swings his boot into the thug's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy. Stacy looks.  Bartender holds up phone.  Stacy goes over. BARTENDER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do without you inhibiting my business. Stacy just scowls, takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Breaks.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Hangs up.  Goes back to Uncle John.  Picks up his cue aga STACY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been fired.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VALENTINE'S HOUSE. L.A. DAY
dialogues.text: Someone we've never seen before and will never see again stands in Valentine's driveway.  His name is FIELDING. A car comes up.  Another guy, GRAMMS, sits in it.  He wai Eventually Fielding walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:  the burnt garage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine had himself a party, I hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by rote)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My client has already given a statement regarding yesterday's events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A statement?  I wouldn't mind getting a statement.  You see, my client -- the United States Government -- would love to get a statement about a few of the deals going down with your client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deals?  My client is involved in any number of deals at any given moment. You'd have to be more specific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your client have a deal in Long Beach? How about downtown?  There's some folks there -- oh, wait, they're all dead.  Any of this ring a bell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My client is an entrepreneur.  I am his lawyer, not his business manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you wouldn't have any idea how your client continues to make so much fucking money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always been very forward-thinking. He invested wisely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had urgent business in the north. Gramms just laughs.  Just laughs and laughs.  And we leav laughing.  And Fielding not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed takes off an apron, heads out the door.  It's clear th he's not the head chef here -- because the HEAD CHEF, an Anglo, turns, wondering where he's going.  Over this we h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Big Sur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- few hours, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use a vacation.  Of course, I keep forgetting, for you this is a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought of that. (grunt of laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busman's holiday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in Big Sur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where Valentine's scarpered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloke told me. Beat. WILSON (cont'd) (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't go back to your place.  Not till ... this is resolved. Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear it's a nice drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed gets into Wilson's car.  Elaine in there too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson's rented car.  Heading for Big Sur. INT. CAR. Ed drives.  Wilson beside him.  Elaine in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you say, Elaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much -- you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time I saw you, weren't you up for some equity-waiver thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna be in that Michael Mann movie, you know -- with Pacino and DeNiro.  Got three callbacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, those are the breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not no more, they ain't.  I quit that acting shit, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just cooking then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no.  I started writing. Elaine and Wilson exchange glances. EXT. HIGHWAY.  DAY. Onwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy and Uncle John sit and drink.  Uncle John lamenting their monetary loss.  Stacy thinking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We coulda used the other two-and-a-half grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more than a measly few grand in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to know more about Mr. Whatever- his-name-is than he thinks I know about him and his operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like he'd never hire me for real.  Not week-to-week.  I don't have the credentials.  He thinks I'm just a sociopath, someone he can turn to when he needs "plausible denial."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we blew it, didn't we?  He ain't wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savage mimicry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He ain't wrong."  Listen, I know this asshole who did just go to work for him. Full-time.  And this dickhead's parents just told me he took a road trip up the coast.  That's the type of individual gets hired, someone who'll shoot his mouth off to his family while on the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who that English guy is. Some kind of -- (finding the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- courier or something.  Maybe a seller. Maybe a buyer.  But Mr. Avery wanted him, those jigs wanted him -- and I betcha there's a briefcase somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugs?  Cash?  Both if we're lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we gonna get that lucky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While they're all fucking each other over ... couple of parties like us could move right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson's car. Closer to Big Sur.  Scenery more magnificent. INT. WILSON'S CAR. Ed still driving.  Wilson next to him.  Opening a new cigarette pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wondering something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any friends, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I suppose.  Call 'em that, yeah. Down the boozer Saturday night.  Meet some of the lads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little more pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends and colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't count on very many people, that's the trouble.  Number of times a decent job's been cocked up ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor baby. Little back-seat sarcasm there.  Wilson looks kind of bit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Useless gits.  I was gonna do the Post Office once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What post office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lot.  The whole British bloody Post Office.  I had a brilliant plan -- all worked out -- work of genius, it was. Could I get anybody interested?  No -- they're too busy pinching orange squash from the milkman.  Lazy sods.  Jumble sale on in Watford, they'll be up at the crack of dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just on a higher plane, Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bleeding true, 'n' it. Flicks some cigarette pack paper out the window. EXT. HIGHWAY. The car speeds along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impressive clifftop dwelling.  Isolated on a winding r On a beautiful promontory overlooking the sea.  Valentine RINGS the DOORBELL (actually CHIME).  It's opened by his wife.  SUSAN.  Very well-maintained.  50-something. Surprised to see him.  But not overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exercising my visitation rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss my kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're at college.  Or doesn't your accountant even tell you where the money goes anymore. Valentine goes inside. INT. HOUSE. He looks around.  She doesn't shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made it ... brighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you here, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do. He turns to look at her.  Smiles.  Somehow it doesn't wor her.  One of the reasons she divorced him.  Just one.  Sh sighs.  Resigned to his presence.  Starts to close the do VALENTINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shut the door -- I have people with me. Now she gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of trouble are you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble. Susan SEES Adhara get out of the sporty car parked in the drive and stand against it in a posture of younger chick defiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you can think of somewhere else to take one of your chippies for a quick getaway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. He actually puts his hands on her arms.  To hold her firm while he locks onto her eyes.  And doesn't smile. VALENTINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need ... somewhere remote.  Away from L.A.  For a couple of days. (now the kicker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay for this house too. Susan reads him.  He's not claiming ownership rights.  He telling her this house, because of the connection to him, a target of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done? The Land Cruiser pulls up outside.  Avery emerges, comes over, comes in.  Susan notes the bodyguards out there as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Valentine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren't followed. (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. Valentine lets Susan go.  Knowing she's now speechless at what's turned into, as far as she's concerned, a home invasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving, looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's ... what's-his-name -- Fred --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You know his name is Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I don't live with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to him.  Go to his studio, or writers workshop or artists colony, Esselin retreat, nudist camp --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a couple of days this whole thing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's looking for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go now. Encouraging, if not in fact ushering, her towards a bedro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been five minutes and I'm packing to leave again.  I can't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, your life is Shit, and I'm to blame.  It's that simple. That does it.  Susan turns on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is that simple.  I blame you for everything.  Losing inhibitions and chicks without bras didn't have to lead to hardcore porno in every American household:  that was you.  The first on your block to turn on a camera in a hot tub and peddle it to your friends.  A little recreational pot didn't inevitably have to lead to the eventual devastation of the inner cities:  you made that happen, the first time you bought a bigger stash than you yourself meant to smoke.  It happened when you made your first buck hyping some so-called "event" that was over before it began or marketed some "product" whose only value was its instant disposability.  You were the first person to see there was a lot of money to be made selling Navajo rugs -- you've even stolen from the fucking Indians!  You looked at Charlie Manson when all he had to show for himself was a guitar instead of a knife and saw another merry prankster, the freedom of the frontier.  Your pal here -- (Avery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- He saw gated communities.  Rich people coming to him with their money, terrified of what people like you had left of this society.  Why invest in a marriage and children when you had him?  He's your oracle.  But you couldn't even trust in friendship, could you?  Still he's the dog you call for its dinner.  Because everything that might once have been fun or nice or sweet you had to turn mean and cold and sour.  That was your "genius," Terry.  Haven't you read your own press?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson and his friends pull in.  Get out of the car. Stretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finding herself at another shithole)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, you just like the reassuring smell of disinfectant? Wilson just heads for the motel office.  Elaine and Ed fo a little distance behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Elaine.  You even know what he's saying half the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I know what he means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adhara sways in a hammock.  Staring at Valentine.  Wantin know what the hell is going on. Valentine stands smoking at the rail, looking out over th dark sea.  Ignoring Adhara.  Avery sits at a table. Bodyguards visible inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally, to Avery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do any of these guys cook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson at the car.  Elaine and Ed watching. Ed has gathered that something has developed between Wils and Elaine.  The way she's looking at Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Reminds me of Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely perceptible nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to miss. Ed sighs.  Awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you just came for the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather be with him than without him. I don't want to be found dead in L.A. Wilson walks back to them.  Looking at Ed as if to say, r to go?  At her as if to say ... maybe farewell. EXT. VALENTINE HOUSE.  NIGHT. Tableau.  Evening has descended.  Surfaces glisten from a light drizzling rain. INT. VALENTINE HOUSE, BEDROOM.  NIGHT. Adhara, dressing.  Behind her, outside, way out of focus, figure slithers by. INT. VALENTINE HOUSE, LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Valentine and Avery sit watching TV (CELEBRITY REPORT!). is behind them in the kitchen, flipping through <i>Marie magazine.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Turns to look through the sliding glass doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the deck stands Larry, his back to us, facing the ocean. EXT. VALENTINE HOUSE.  BACK YARD.  NIGHT. Looking toward the house, Larry in the foreground, facing He takes a bite from a cinnamon granola bar, then looks a unhappily as he chews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. EXT. VALENTINE HOUSE, ANOTHER ANGLE.  NIGHT. Looking at the house from the top of the hill.  Rick stan in the driveway next to Valentine's car, smoking a cigare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson and Ed watching him.  Wilson nods his head to the left, and Ed moves in that direction.  Wilson moves quiet off to the right. INT. VALENTINE HOUSE.  LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Valentine and Avery, still watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:  the channel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the news. Avery starts looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the remote? Suddenly, we hear a CAR ALARM.  Tom looks up from his magazine.  Valentine looks to Avery, who shakes his head: It's nothing. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  DRIVEWAY.  NIGHT. Rick turns and looks up the driveway toward the sound.  H puts his cigarette out. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BACK YARD.  NIGHT. Larry has turned toward the sound as well.  Through a partially obscured side entrance, he sees Rick walking up driveway. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  DRIVEWAY.  NIGHT. Rick walks away from us, toward the vehicle (the Land Cru they drove here) parked up the driveway.  We lose sight o him as he crosses to the driver's side.  The alarm goes o We hold for several beats.  He doesn't emerge. INT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Valentine and Avery are still looking for the remote.  Av stops, his attention drawn to the fact that he hasn't hea anything from Larry.  He crosses to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driveway, car at the top partially visible.  No sign Rick.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: His brow furrows.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Notices this, looks out toward the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as before, except Larry isn't there.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Moves to the sliding glass door to get a better look at t deck and back yard.  Still no Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Larry?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Leaves the window and moves to Valentine.  Tom has joined them.  After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn all the lights out.  I'll get Adhara. Tom begins looking for the light switches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening? Avery is already heading for the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from the windows. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BACK YARD.  NIGHT. Tableau.  Avery exits the kitchen and takes the surroundi porch to the bedroom.  Are we seeing this from someone's INT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BEDROOM.  NIGHT. Adhara, finished dressing, looking at herself in the mirr The lights behind her go off.  She turns to see Avery com toward her to turn off the lights by the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, you've heard of knocking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, what -- He takes her by the arm.  Firmly, but not roughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. She sees in his expression that something is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  LIVING ROOM.  NIGHT. Tom and Valentine have finally found the light switches, the room is dark.  Valentine moves slowly to the window, takes a tentative peek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driveway.  Hard to see.  Is there something moving ou the shed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I said stay away from the window.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Entering the kitchen with Adhara in tow.  He brings her around behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody in the kitchen. Valentine and Tom move to join Avery and Adhara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the counter. Everyone moves behind the large counter in the center of kitchen and crouches down.  They have a wall behind them all the windows in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Avery and Tom have drawn their guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think someone is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't find ... (what are their names?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... two of our guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fucking typical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did somebody call the cops? Tom snorts.  Avery looks at Valentine:  Haven't you told girl anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm taking care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are fucking nuts, I'm calling -- She starts to stand.  Valentine pulls her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Avery. Avery looks to Tom, who nods toward the back porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silhouetted figure is tentatively making its way along porch, trying not to be seen.  We don't get a very clear glimpse.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Draws his gun and takes aim.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIGURE
dialogues.text: Careful not to become fully visible, but growing more courageous with each step.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Locked on him, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Puts Adhara's hand to her ears.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIGURE
dialogues.text: We see a little more now than we have before.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: He sees enough.  Squeezes off a series of SHOTS, the muzz flash strobing the kitchen area like a flashbulb, Adhara Valentine flinching.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIGURE
dialogues.text: Hit.  Spinning and collapsing to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Lowers his gun.  Turns to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch my back. Avery moves out from behind the counter and heads for the body. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BACK PORCH.  NIGHT. Avery makes his way to the figure, which is on its stomac and writhing slightly.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Careful.  Takes the gun and turns the body over.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Stares up at him, choking on his last few breaths.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Puzzled.  What the hell is this guy doing here?  He start feeling around Stacy's jacket for anything useful, but is interrupted when his hand EXPLODES, accompanied by the so of a gunshot.  He screams in pain. INT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  KITCHEN.  NIGHT. Valentine and Adhara drop to the floor.  Tom, gun raised pointing, tries to see who shot Avery. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BACK PORCH.  NIGHT. Avery is turning toward his assailant, but not fast enoug A shot rings out and part of his neck disappears in a blo of blood.  Stunned, he falls on his side, gasping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle John.  Close by, huddled by the lip of the cliff. starts to move cautiously toward Avery and Stacy. INT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  KITCHEN.  NIGHT. Tom squints, trying to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery's down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece of Uncle John's silhouette appears.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Fires at it.  Didn't hit anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck this. Tom jumps up and runs for the living room, firing his gun front of him toward where he last saw Uncle John's silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING AREA
dialogues.text: Tom runs through and reaches the sliding doors to the bac porch.  A portion of the frame SPLINTERS from a gun shot he gains access to the other side of the back porch. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BACK PORCH.  NIGHT. Tom is through the sliding doors and trying to make his w around to the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Crouched behind the opposite end of the porch, sticks his head up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom crossing to the steps, slips on the damp wood, tries right himself.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Squeezes off two shots.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is shot in the ankle as he is about to reach the steps. yelps in pain, tries to raise his gun.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Crouched down.  A shot flies over his head.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Stops shooting.  Tries dragging his shattered ankle to th steps.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Looks over the edge of the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom turning toward the steps.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Fires at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Screams again as his elbow of his gun hand disintegrates. slips on the first step and tumbles down, the gun bouncin beside him.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Sees this.  Stands up to cross the back porch.  Takes a s forward but is stopped by a bullet in the chest (about th only clean shot anybody makes).  He looks down at himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He looks up to SEE:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Near death.  Gun in his good hand.  He squeezes the trigg again.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
dialogues.text: A small black hole appears in his cheek.  He blinks, begi to raise his hand to his face, and collapses.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Exhales and rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Still trying to get to his feet.  He gives up and just li there, panting.

dialogues.speaker: A HAND
dialogues.text: Reaches for the gun beside Tom.  Tilt up with it to revea

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: He puts the gun in his jacket and slides away. INT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  KITCHEN.  NIGHT. Valentine and Adhara are still stuck behind the counter. Valentine sees the shadowy shape of Ed slipping behind th back porch.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Decides to make a run for it, following Tom's route, away from Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Valentine runs to the sliding door, smack into:

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Standing there.  Wet.  Mad.  He grabs Valentine by the sh and pushes him back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Bounces off the couch and onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Comes toward him.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Grabs a lamp off an end table and hurls it at Wilson.  It careens off Wilson's arm and shatters.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Is almost on him now.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Tries to scramble away.  Throwing anything he can get his hands on at.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Who keeps coming.  He grabs Valentine, pulls him up, then throws him into the television.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Crashes into the TV face first and bounces to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Goes to him, grabs him by the neck with one hand and pull out his gun with the other.  He seems about to speak when suddenly he screams instead.

dialogues.speaker: ADHARA
dialogues.text: Has just stuck a kitchen knife into Wilson's back.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Turns instinctively and whips the pistol around, smashing Adhara in the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ADHARA
dialogues.text: Hits the ground.  She won't be retaliating.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: In agony, spinning, trying to reach the knife in his back but IT'S JUST BEYOND HIS REACH.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Scrambles through the sliding glass door. EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  BACK PORCH.  NIGHT. Valentine stumbles out.  Notices Avery slumped on the dec mortally wounded.  Goes to him -- as if concerned -- but actually just to take the gun.  Then runs off the porch toward the STEPS that lead down to the sea.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Comes out after him, the knife still in his back.  So int on catching Valentine he fails at first to notice Avery l in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Has just barely managed to reach Stacy's pistol.  Raises weakly.  Points it at Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Seems to feel it.  Turns.  Locks eyes with Avery.  Avery could already have shot him.  But there's a momentary sen recognition:  both of them just foot soldiers for fat cat and Avery's is not worth saving.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Lowers the gun.  Nods in the direction Valentine went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that way ... Wilson moves on.  Avery just lies there, presumably to di EXT. BIG SUR HOUSE.  STEPS.  NIGHT. Valentine hurries down the rickety steps.  Trying not to in the darkness, though there are tiny Malibu lights illuminating the steep and winding wooden framework. EXT. BEACH.  NIGHT. A rocky cove.  Valentine looks back up the way he came, HEARING the FOOTSTEPS coming down after him.  Backs away few paces on the slippery rocks.  Falls. Lands on the crumpled, dead body of LARRY, the bodyguard, was thrown off the cliff.  Valentine recoils.  When Wilso appears, Valentine FIRES at him.  A wild shot that only m Wilson duck momentarily.  Valentine scrambles to his feet runs on.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Jumps down from the steps.  Stops for a moment and leans back against the railing.  Bends at the knees slightly.

dialogues.speaker: THE KNIFE
dialogues.text: The handle is forced upward just enough to be reachable n

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Grimacing, pulls the knife out and discards it.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER DOWN THE BEACH
dialogues.text: Valentine runs.  Or tries to.  It's dark and the ground i treacherous.  The beach runs out pretty soon.  Now just rocks.  Maybe he thought he could get around the rocks on point at the other end.  But he can't see very far ahead. And the tide is in, water making any escape extremely difficult.  He tries to scramble over some rocks.  They'r wet, slippery.  He falls, cries out as he literally break ankle.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: A dark figure.  Coming into focus.  Walking inexorably th way.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Painfully rights himself.  A small bone protrudes from hi broken ankle.  He FIRES at Wilson, gun in one hand, other hand gripping his wrist to try and steady it.  Doing his to aim.  But the SHOTS miss their mark.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Steadily coming.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Out of bullets now.  Gun CLICKING crazily on empty.  He simply drops it.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Now stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO OF THEM
dialogues.text: Both breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me. This is not what Valentine expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Jenny. (closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Jenny. (closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the deal.  Whatever fucking deal you had to kill my daughter for when she found out about it, you bastard. Wilson drops to the ground too, in a passionate fury, sta strangling Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.  Tell me about it, you fucking bastard. Easing up just enough for Valentine to sputter out a response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could've had the deal!  I would've handed it to her if she wanted.  I would have given her everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why then.  Why did you do it! They're locked in a kind of embrace.  Sprayed by the wave crashing into the rocks.  Sweating and gasping and exhaus and hurt and furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't want to share it, she wanted to stop it.  To stop me.  She said she'd turn me in.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Shock of recognition on his face.  At those words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said, "You go ahead with this, I'll turn you in, Terry." Wilson sits back.  Panting.  Totally spent.  The two of t Both on the ground now.  Whatever energy they had left dr -- Valentine from his confession, Wilson from hearing it. Valentine shaking, sobbing.  Still not realizing the path folly of his actions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was serious.  She would have done it. She had the phone in her hand.  She was going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Knows that the girl he loved ... loved Valentine, too.  H heard the truth, the last vestige of revenge has vanished He gets up and walks away.  Leaving the quivering shell o Valentine behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adhara wakes up.  Hand to her smashed cheek and mouth.  B it's not her hand.  It's Valentine's.  She sort of shuffl away from him along the floor.  Sits against a wall holdi her face.  Valentine sits back against an opposite wall. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson, lost in thought.  Accepts a drink from a FLIGHT ATTENDANT.  We can see it pains him to reach for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta. After setting the glass down, his other hand goes to the shoulder where his stab wound was no doubt only temporari dealt with. FLASH CUTS: WILSON. At the roadside hotel, grimacing. ELAINE. Cleaning his wound. Wilson rubs his shoulder. The AMERICAN LADY in the seat beside him heard the way he said thanks to the Flight Attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're English. A small beat (which he takes each time he responds).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can never decide what I like better. Leaving home, or coming back.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Takes this in. FLASH CUTS: WILSON. Shaving in the mirror at his L.A. motel. He stops WILSON. In the car leaving Valentine's house. Fingering t picture of Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have preferred staying home, me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a reluctant traveller, then. Wilson nods. FLASH CUTS: WILSON. In the car with Elaine and Ed, driving back from Sur. Everyone in their own world. WILSON. At Ed's house. Saying goodbye. WILSON AND ED. Shake hands. ED. Watching him get into Elaine's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got called out to L.A., unexpected like, to do a job of work. FLASH CUTS: WILSON. At the airport, staring at Elaine. ELAINE. Staring back. WILSON AND ELAINE. She embraces him. ELAINE. She watches him leave. WILSON. Disappearing into the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be looking forward to getting back, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Another little matter needs attending to soon as I return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No rest for the wicked. Wilson nods, exhales. FLASH CUT: WILSON. In the cab on the way to Ed's, at the beginning o the film. Watching the lights go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been away a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where else? Longer beat.  He actually turns to look at her now.  Take her in, then looks forward again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out on a oil rig.  In the North Sea. Nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine years? (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that legal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, time off for good behavior, you know.  I shouldn't have even been there -- it was these other blokes who shoulda gone in my place.  I got lumbered with the job they were responsible for.  I don't mind pulling me own cart, but not someone else's, know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you stuck it out, anyway, all that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to, didn't I.  Nothing else for it. Then just when I'd finished my nine years -- my contract -- wallop, I had to bugger off to the States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting slightly to his "colorful" language)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you need a rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could do, yeah. Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But first I gotta give these lads a talking to, these geezers what sent me up the river, in a manner of speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones whose burden you took upon your own shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And he turns away, to the window.  Looks at the blue sky. Sips his drink.  Then, hard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them next.
